title: PwC Considers Changes to U.K. Auditor Pay to Avoid Conflicts of Interest
text:
PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP is considering changes to how its U.K. audit partners are being remunerated to avoid potential conflicts of interest.

The potential changes to auditor partners’ pay and bonuses are part of a wider review of how its U.K. business is operating.

Karthik Ramanna, a professor of business and public policy at the University of Oxford’s Blavatnik School of Government, in a report published Friday called for audit firms to resort to independent, external remuneration committees to advise on audit partners’ pay.

Mr. Ramanna in the report, which was commissioned by PwC in June, also suggested for audit firms’ boards to test internal controls and for junior-level staff to receive more hands-on training.

His recommendations come amid increased scrutiny in Britain over the quality of the audits provided by PwC and the other Big Four accounting firms: Deloitte & Touche LLP, Ernst & Young LLP and KPMG LLP.

Regulators and lawmakers have suggested various changes to overhaul the industry, including an operational and even a structural split of companies’ audit and nonaudit businesses.

“The public’s disillusionment with auditing will continue until the firms can credibly demonstrate that they are managing conflicts of interests,” Mr. Ramanna wrote in his report. “This requires both an organizational architecture that is more open to external scrutiny and the firms being more open to take substantive actions when the scrutiny so suggests,” he said.

He presented his findings to PwC’s audit partners this week.

“We recognize that we need to continue to reinforce a challenge mind-set and are actively considering all of the recommendations,” said Hemione Hudson, head of audit at PwC U.K.

The country’s regulator for audit and accounting, the Financial Reporting Council, in July criticized the decline in PwC’s audit quality, stating that 65% of audits provided by the company in 2018 were considered good or in need of only minor improvements, down from 84% in 2017.

PwC in June announced various measures aimed at revamping its U.K. audit business. The company said it would split its U.K. assurance practice into two distinct businesses and spend an additional £30 million ($36.9 million) a year on the audit division. As part of that, PwC said it would hire more than 500 auditors in addition to the 5,500 it already employs.

description: An academic report commissioned by the professional services firm recommends handing oversight over audit partners’ pay to an external body.
